questions.question: What consumes the time of most of the littuns?
What example shows that the boys are still affected by the rules of their old lives?

choices.answer: The bigguns take care of the littuns.
The littuns still cry for their mothers.
Roger throws rocks at the littuns but aims to miss.
The children try to stick to their mealtimes & routines.

questions.question: Why does Jack paint his face?

choices.answer: To camoflauge his face to hunt the pig.
To assert his authority on the island.
To show that he is different from the group.

questions.question: How has Jack's personality developed on the island?

choices.answer: Changing into a mystic and poet.

questions.question: What causes Jack and the hunters to neglect the fire?

choices.answer: They are trying to build a canoe.
They are becoming more savage and only think about hunting
They don't really know how to keep the fire going.
They think the dark will help settle the other boys.

questions.question: What is the main conflict of this chapter?

choices.answer: The littuns getting diarrhea from the fruit.
The disappearance of the boy with the birthmark.
The boys fear of the beastie.
The tension between Jack and Ralph.

questions.question: What type of conflict is represented by the tension between Jack and Ralph?
What type of conflict is represented by Ralph's inability to forgive Jack?
Why does Jack refuse to give Piggy meat?

choices.answer: Piggy didn't help them capture the pig.
